thread.title: Dylann Roof stopped by another church after Charleston shooting
thread.title_full: Dylann Roof stopped by another church after Charleston shooting

author: JASON SILVERSTEIN
title: Dylann Roof stopped by another church after Charleston shooting
text:
Dylann Roof stopped by another black church after Charleston massacre, court documents say Dylann Roof stopped by another church after Charleston shooting Dylann Roof in his first court appearance. (POOL/REUTERS) NEW YORK DAILY NEWS Updated:   7:59 AM 
Charleston church shooter Dylann Roof stopped by another black church the night of his Bible study massacre in 2015, court papers show. 
Newly unsealed documents in Roof’s federal case cite GPS data that was not presented in his trial. The records show that after Roof gunned down nine parishioners at the Emanuel AME Church on June 17, he stopped at another house of worship — the Branch AME Church — and shut off his GPS device for several minutes. Like Emanuel, the Branch church was holding its weekly Bible study that night. 
There is no indication that Roof entered the church, and it’s unclear if anyone was still there when he arrived. 
Prosecutors argue that this shows Roof was contemplating another attack, but defense attorneys have said there is no evidence of this. 
Convicted church shooter Dylann Roof wants new federal trial 
In his FBI interview after his arrest, Roof told police he was too tired after his Emanuel massacre to keep shooting. One survivor of the shooting said Roof put his gun to his head and pulled the trigger — but there were no bullets. He then fled the church, and was caught in another town the next morning. Roof gunned down nine parishioners at the Emanuel AME Church in Charleston in June 2015. (CARLO ALLEGRI/REUTERS) 
Other court documents say Roof admitted to a coworker that he was racist, and also regularly talked about Adolf Hitler and said he made sure to keep only 88 Facebook friends, referencing a number used as Nazi code for “Heil Hitler.” 
Roof was convicted in December of all 33 federal hate crime charges against him, and he was sentenced to death. He is now awaiting another trial, this time in state court, for his nine murders. 
With News Wire Services
